Apple Inc..passage: Apple Inc. is an American multinational technology company headquartered in Cupertino, California, that designs, develops, and sells consumer electronics, computer software, and online services. The company's hardware products include the iPhone smartphone, the iPad tablet computer, the Mac personal computer, the iPod portable media player, the Apple Watch smartwatch, the Apple TV digital media player, and the HomePod smart speaker. Apple's software includes the macOS and iOS operating systems, the iTunes media player, the Safari web browser, and the iLife and iWork creativity and productivity suites. Its online services include the iTunes Store, the iOS App Store, and Mac App Store, Apple Music, and iCloud. Apple was founded by Steve Jobs, Steve Wozniak, and Ronald Wayne in April 1976 to develop and sell Wozniak's Apple I personal computer. It was incorporated as Apple Computer, Inc. in January 1977, and sales of its computers, including the Apple II, grew quickly. Apple went public in 1980 to instant financial success. Over the next few years, Apple shipped new computers featuring innovative graphical user interfaces, such as the original Macintosh in 1984, and Apple's marketing advertisements for its products received widespread critical acclaim. However, the high price of its products and limited application library caused problems, as did power struggles between executives. In 1985, Wozniak departed Apple amicably and remained a shareholder, while Jobs resigned to found NeXT.

Amazon.com.passage: Amazon.com, Inc. is an American multinational technology company based in Seattle, Washington that focuses on e-commerce, cloud computing, digital streaming, and artificial intelligence. It is the largest internet-based retailer in the world by total sales and market capitalization. Amazon.com started as an online bookstore, but soon diversified, selling DVDs, CDs, MP3s, software, video games, electronics, apparel, furniture, food, toys, and jewelry. The company also produces consumer electronics—notably, Amazon Kindle e-book readers, Amazon Echo smart speakers, and Amazon Fire tablets—and is the world's largest provider of cloud infrastructure services (IaaS and PaaS) through its Amazon Web Services (AWS) subsidiary. Amazon has also expanded into the delivery of groceries, furniture, and other home goods through Amazon Fresh, Amazon Prime, Amazon Restaurants, and Amazon Home Services. Amazon's initial public offering (IPO) took place on May 15, 1997, and the company's stock price climbed to a peak of US$1,047 a share in 2017 before falling back. In 2019, Amazon surpassed Microsoft to become the most valuable company in the world, with a market capitalization of over $1 trillion. Amazon is the world's largest retailer by total sales and the largest online retailer in the world by total sales. In 2017, Amazon acquired Whole Foods Market for $13.4 billion, which vastly increased Amazon's presence as a brick-and-mortar retailer.

Microsoft Corporation.passage: Microsoft Corporation is an American multinational technology company that develops software, hardware, and services. It was founded by Bill Gates and Paul Allen on April 4, 1975, and is headquartered in Redmond, Washington. Microsoft is the world's largest software maker by revenue, and one of the world's most valuable companies. Microsoft develops and licenses a wide range of software products for various computing devices, including operating systems, server software, productivity software, and video game consoles. Its flagship products include the Windows operating system, Microsoft Office suite, and Internet Explorer web browser. In addition to software development, Microsoft is also involved in hardware manufacturing and selling, such as the Xbox gaming console and Surface line of tablets. The company also offers online services, including the Bing search engine, Skype communication software, and OneDrive cloud storage. Microsoft has a strong presence in the gaming industry, with its Xbox brand being one of the leading gaming consoles in the market. The company also has a significant presence in the professional sports industry, with its Microsoft Teams collaboration software being used by many teams in the National Football League (NFL) and National Basketball Association (NBA). Microsoft has a long history of innovation and has been involved in several groundbreaking technologies, including the development of the first graphical user interface (GUI) for personal computers with Windows, the creation of the .NET framework for developing software, and the development of the Kinect motion sensor for Xbox. The company has faced several legal challenges over the years, including antitrust lawsuits and patent disputes. However, Microsoft has continued to grow and expand its business, with a strong focus on innovation and customer satisfaction.

Alphabet Inc..passage: Alphabet Inc. is an American multinational conglomerate headquartered in Mountain View, California. It was created through a corporate restructuring of Google in 2015, and is the parent company of Google and several other companies founded within the Alphabet umbrella. The company's portfolio includes several successful ventures, such as Google's core search and advertising business, as well as subsidiaries such as Google Cloud, Google Ventures, and Google X, which focuses on developing new technologies and products. Other subsidiaries include Nest Labs, which produces smart home products, and Waymo, which is developing self-driving car technology. Alphabet Inc. is one of the world's largest and most valuable companies, with a market capitalization of over $1 trillion as of 2021. Its success is largely attributed to its ability to innovate and adapt to changing market conditions, as well as its strong focus on research and development. The company has also faced criticism for its dominance in the tech industry and its impact on privacy and competition. In 2020, the Federal Trade Commission fined Alphabet $170 million for violating a consent decree related to its acquisition of the mobile advertising company AdMob. Despite these challenges, Alphabet Inc. continues to be a leader in the tech industry and a major player in the global economy. Its focus on innovation and its ability to adapt to changing market conditions make it a company to watch in the years to come.

Facebook.passage: Facebook is an American online social media and social networking service based in Menlo Park, California. Its website was launched on February 4, 2004, by Mark Zuckerberg, along with fellow Harvard College students and roommates Eduardo Saverin, Andrew McCollum, Dustin Moskovitz, and Chris Hughes. The founders initially limited the website's membership to Harvard students, but later expanded it to other colleges in the Boston area, the Ivy League, and eventually, to any university student with a valid email address. Membership was eventually opened to anyone with a valid email address, and the site began to attract users outside of the university population. Facebook has more than 2.7 billion monthly active users as of January 2021, which is roughly 36% of the world's population. As of May 2021, Facebook is the most popular social networking site in the world, followed by YouTube, WhatsApp, and Messenger. Facebook's revenue was $70.7 billion in 2019, and it is expected to reach $85.9 billion in 2020. The company has also faced controversies over its handling of user data, election interference, and its role in spreading misinformation. Facebook's mission is to give people the power to build community and bring the world closer together. The company aims to create a platform that allows people to connect with each other, share information, and build relationships. Facebook's features include the ability to create a personal profile, share photos and videos, send messages, and join groups based on common interests. The site also allows users to connect with friends, family, and acquaintances, and to create and join groups based on shared interests.

Berkshire Hathaway Inc..passage: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. is an American multinational conglomerate holding company headquartered in Omaha, Nebraska, United States. The company is led by chairman and CEO Warren Buffett, who is considered one of the most successful investors in the world. Berkshire Hathaway is the fourth-largest public company in the world, with a market capitalization of over $500 billion as of 2021. Berkshire Hathaway was founded in 1839 as a textile manufacturer, and it grew to become one of the largest companies in the world by the early 20th century. However, the company struggled in the latter half of the 20th century as it failed to adapt to changing market conditions and technological advancements. In 1965, Warren Buffett began purchasing shares in Berkshire Hathaway, and by 1970 he had acquired a controlling interest in the company. Under Buffett's leadership, Berkshire Hathaway shifted its focus from textiles to investing in a diverse range of companies across various industries. Today, the company's portfolio includes well-known brands such as Coca-Cola, Apple, American Express, and Geico, among others. Berkshire Hathaway also has significant investments in the insurance industry, including GEICO, Berkshire Hathaway Homestate Companies, and General Re Corporation. Berkshire Hathaway is known for its long-term investment strategy, which emphasizes buying and holding onto companies for many years. The company was formed in 2000, when Chase Manhattan Corporation merged with J.P. Morgan & Co. Johnson.passage: Johnson was a prominent figure in the American Civil Rights Movement, who played a key role in the struggle for racial equality in the United States during the 1950s and 1960s. He was born on January 15, 1930, in Montgomery, Alabama, and grew up in a family that was deeply involved in the struggle for civil rights. Johnson's father was a Baptist minister, and his mother was a schoolteacher. Johnson attended segregated public schools in Montgomery, where he was an excellent student and a standout athlete. He went on to attend the historically black Tuskegee Institute, where he studied mechanical engineering. After graduating in 1952, Johnson worked as a teacher and a coach in rural Alabama. In 1955, Johnson became involved in the civil rights movement when he was recruited by the Montgomery Improvement Association to serve as a leader in the bus boycott. He played a key role in organizing the boycott, which lasted for over a year and ultimately led to the desegregation of Montgomery's public transportation system. Johnson's leadership in the bus boycott made him a national figure, and he went on to become a prominent leader in the civil rights movement. He worked closely with Martin Luther King Jr. and other civil rights leaders, and played a key role in organizing the March on Washington in 1963. Johnson was also a key figure in the Selma to Montgomery marches, which were a series of protests that took place in 1965. The marches were organized to demand voting rights for African Americans, and they were met with violent resistance from state and local authorities.

Exxon Mobil Corporation.passage: Exxon Mobil Corporation is an American multinational oil and gas corporation headquartered in Irving, Texas. It is the largest direct descendant of John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Company, and was formed on November 30, 1999, by the merger of Exxon and Mobil. The company is the largest oil refiner in the world, with a refining capacity of 5.5 million barrels per day. It is also one of the world's largest producers of natural gas, and the largest producer of oil in the United States. Exxon Mobil's operations are divided into two main businesses: Upstream and Downstream. The Upstream business is focused on oil and gas exploration, development, and production, while the Downstream business is focused on refining, marketing, and distributing petroleum products. The company operates in most countries around the world, and has a diverse portfolio of energy resources, including oil, natural gas, coal, and renewable energy sources. Exxon Mobil is one of the largest publicly traded companies in the world, with a market capitalization of over $200 billion. It is also one of the most profitable companies in the world, with a net income of over $20 billion in 2019. The company has been involved in several controversies over the years, including allegations of environmental pollution and human rights abuses. However, it has also been recognized for its corporate social responsibility initiatives, including its support for education and community development programs.

Nest Labs.passage: Nest Labs is a home automation company that produces a range of smart home products, including thermostats, cameras, and smoke alarms. The company was founded in 2010 by Tony Fadell and Matt Rogers, who previously worked on the development of the iPod and iPhone at Apple Inc. Nest Labs is headquartered in Palo Alto, California, and has offices in several other locations around the world. Nest Labs' flagship product is the Nest Learning Thermostat, which uses machine learning algorithms to learn a user's schedule and preferences over time, and adjust the temperature accordingly. The thermostat also has a feature called "Auto-Away," which detects when no one is home and adjusts the temperature to save energy. In addition to thermostats, Nest Labs also produces a line of smart cameras, including the Nest Cam Indoor and Nest Cam Outdoor. These cameras use computer vision technology to detect motion and send alerts to the user's phone or tablet. They also have features like person detection and facial recognition, which allow users to identify specific people and receive alerts when they enter or leave the home. Nest Labs' smoke and carbon monoxide alarms are also smart, with features like voice alerts and a mobile app that allows users to silence alarms and test the batteries. The alarms also have a feature called "Split-Spectrum Sensor," which uses two different types of sensors to detect smoke and carbon monoxide more accurately. Overall, Nest Labs' products are designed to make home automation more accessible and user-friendly, with a focus on energy efficiency and safety.

P&G.passage: Procter & Gamble (P&G) is an American multinational consumer goods corporation headquartered in downtown Cincinnati, Ohio, United States. Its products include cleaning agents and personal care products. P&G was founded in 1837 by William Procter and James Gamble, both of whom were born in the United Kingdom. Initially, the company produced soap and candles. In 1859, it launched its first branded product, Ivory soap. P&G has since expanded its product line to include many household names, such as Tide laundry detergent, Crest toothpaste, and Pampers diapers. The company operates in over 70 countries and has a workforce of approximately 95,000 employees. P&G is known for its strong branding and marketing strategies, which have helped it become one of the largest and most successful consumer goods companies in the world.

qae_pairs.question: What year did P&G launch its first branded product?
qae_pairs.explanation: In 1859, it launched its first branded product, Ivory soap.

Texas.passage: Texas is a state in the Southern United States, bordered by Mexico to the west, New Mexico to the west and north, Oklahoma to the north, Arkansas to the northeast, Louisiana to the east, and the Gulf of Mexico to the southeast. Texas has an area of 268,581 square miles and a population of over 29 million residents. Houston is the most populous city in Texas and the fourth most populous city in the United States, while San Antonio is the second most populous city in Texas and the seventh most populous city in the United States. Dallas–Fort Worth and Greater Houston are the fourth and fifth most populous metropolitan statistical areas in the United States, respectively. Texas is nicknamed the Lone Star State to signify Texas as a former independent republic and as a reminder of the state's struggle for independence from Mexico. The state's annexation as the 28th state of the United States in 1845 is still celebrated in Texas as an important milestone in the history of the state.

qae_pairs.explanation: Dallas–Fort Worth and Greater Houston are the fourth and fifth most populous metropolitan statistical areas in the United States, respectively.

qae_pairs.explanation: Texas is nicknamed the Lone Star State to signify Texas as a former independent republic and as a reminder of the state's struggle for independence from Mexico.

Upstream.passage: Upstream is a term used in the context of software development to refer to the source code of a software project that is not yet released or published. It is the code that is being actively developed and modified by the project's developers. The term "upstream" is used to distinguish it from "downstream" code, which refers to the version of the software that has been released and is being used by end-users. Upstream development is typically done by a project's core developers, who are responsible for adding new features, fixing bugs, and improving the overall quality of the software. The upstream code is often shared with the wider community of developers who are contributing to the project, either through a version control system like Git or through a code hosting platform like GitHub. Upstream development is an important part of the open-source software ecosystem, as it allows developers to collaborate and share their work with others. It also allows end-users to benefit from the latest features and improvements to the software, as they are incorporated into the downstream code. However, upstream development can also be challenging, as it requires a high degree of coordination and communication between developers, as well as a willingness to accept and incorporate feedback from others.

qae_pairs.question: What is the role of GitHub in upstream development?
qae_pairs.explanation: GitHub is a code hosting platform that allows developers to share their work with others and collaborate on software projects. Answer: GitHub is a code hosting platform that allows developers to share their work with others and collaborate on software projects.

John D. Rockefeller's.passage: John D. Rockefeller was an American industrialist, philanthropist, and the founder of the Standard Oil Company. He was born on July 8, 1839, in Richford, New York, and died on May 23, 1937, in Ormond Beach, Florida. Rockefeller revolutionized the petroleum industry and became one of the richest people in history. He was also a major philanthropist, donating millions to various causes, including education and public health. Rockefeller's business practices were controversial, and he faced criticism for his monopolistic tactics. However, his contributions to the development of the United States and the betterment of humanity cannot be denied.

qae_pairs.question: What was the location of John D. Rockefeller's death?
qae_pairs.explanation: Rockefeller's business practices were controversial, and he faced criticism for his monopolistic tactics.
